skills.name: Form equations in the form y = kx from direct proportion tables
Understand how changing the constant of proportionality affects the slope of a direct proportion graph
Compare the gradient of two linear functions where one is given algebraically and one is given as a graph.
Compare the gradient of two linear functions where one is given algebraically and one is given as a table of values.
Compare the gradient of two linear functions where one is given as a table of values and one is given as a graph.

explanations.A: This would be the equation for car A... Look at the steepness of the lines. Is car B traveling faster or slower?
explanations.B: Although car B looks to have a shorter line than A, when thinking about the speed on a distance-time graph, we need to look at the steepness of the line!
explanations.C: Car A has a steeper line than car B which means car B is traveling slower than 33 meters per second. The only equation with a slower speed would be ùë¶ = 18ùë• as this represents 18 meters per second!
explanations.D: I think you might have doubled the speed of car A but look at the steepness of the lines, is car B traveling faster or slower..?

explanations.A: I think you might be trying to double the speed of car C, but look at the steepness of the lines. Is car D traveling faster or slower..?
explanations.B: Car C has a steeper line than car D which means car D is traveling slower than 38 meters per second. The only equation with a slower speed would be ùë¶ = 20ùë• as this represents 20 meters per second!
explanations.C: This would be the equation for car C... Look at the steepness of the lines, is car D traveling faster or slower?
explanations.D: Although car D looks to have a shorter line than C, when thinking about the speed on a distance-time graph, we need to look at the steepness of the line!

explanations.A: You have correctly worked out the rates, but have accidentally swapped them over!
explanations.B: You have correctly worked out the rate of filling for pool B, but double-check it for pool A. To find the rate, do gallons √∑ minutes!
explanations.C: You have correctly worked out the rate of filling for pool B, but double-check it for pool A. To find the rate, we don't subtract, we divide!
explanations.D: To get the rate of fill for pool A we do gallons √∑ minutes. 400 √∑ 5 = 80, so pool A is filling up at 80 gallons per minute. Looking at the equation given for pool B: ùë¶ = 65ùë•, we know that pool B is filling at a rate of 65 gallons per minute!

explanations.A: You have correctly worked out the rate of filling for pool A, but double-check it for pool B. To find the rate, do gallons √∑ minutes!
explanations.B: You have correctly worked out the rates, but have accidentally swapped them over!
explanations.C: Looking at the equation given for pool A: ùë¶ = 55ùë•, we know that pool A is filling at a rate of 55 gallons per minute. To get the rate of fill for pool B we do gallons √∑ minutes. 300 √∑ 5 = 60, so pool B is filling up at 60 gallons per minute!
explanations.D: You have correctly worked out the rate of filling for pool A, but double-check it for pool B. To find the rate, we don't subtract, we divide!

explanations.A: This is how far Airplane A travels in 1 hour. How far does Airplane B travel in 1 hour? Compare the values to see which has traveled further...
explanations.B: Looking at the graph, we can see Airplane A has traveled 600 miles after 1 hour. Airplane B has the equation ùë¶ = 550ùë•, so after 1 hour will have traveled 550 miles. 600 - 550 = 50 therefore Airplane A has traveled 50 miles further in 1 hour!
explanations.C: This is how far Airplane B travels in 1 hour. How far does Airplane A travel in 1 hour? Compare these values to see which has traveled further...
explanations.D: You have correctly calculated the difference in distance traveled but have accidentally swapped round the Airplanes...

explanations.A: Looking at the graph, we can see Airplane A has traveled 450 miles after 1 hour. Airplane B has the equation ùë¶ = 600ùë•, so after 1 hour will have traveled 600 miles. 600 - 450 = 150 therefore Airplane B has traveled 150 miles further in 1 hour!
explanations.B: This is how far Airplane A travels in 1 hour. How far does Airplane B travel in 1 hour? Compare the values to see which has traveled further...
explanations.C: You have correctly calculated the difference in distance traveled but have accidentally swapped round the Airplanes...
explanations.D: This is how far Airplane B travels in 1 hour. How far does Airplane A travel in 1 hour? Compare these values to see which has traveled further...

explanations.A: This would be the difference in the number of pieces of candy in 10 boxes of candy... The question is asking 'per box', so in 1 box of candy!
explanations.B: I think you are comparing 35 and 300, but 300 is how many pieces of candy are in 10 boxes at company B... How many pieces of candy would be in one box?
explanations.C: We can see from the equation ùë¶ = 35ùë• that company A sells 35 pieces of candy per box. Looking at the table for company B, if there are 300 pieces of candy in 10 boxes then 300 √∑ 10 = 30 pieces of candy per box. So, company A sells 5 more pieces of candy per box than company B!
explanations.D: You have correctly calculated the difference in pieces of candy, but have accidentally swapped round the companies...

explanations.A: You have correctly calculated the difference in pieces of candy, but have accidentally swapped round the companies...
explanations.B: We can see from the equation ùë¶ = 40ùë• that company A sells 40 pieces of candy per box. Looking at the table for company B, if there are 420 pieces of candy in 10 boxes then 420 √∑ 10 = 42 pieces of candy per box. So, company B sells 2 more pieces of candy per box than company A!
explanations.C: This would be the difference in the number of pieces of candy in 10 boxes of candy... The question is asking 'per box', so in 1 box of candy!
explanations.D: I think you are comparing 40 and 420, but 420 is how many pieces of candy are in 10 boxes at company B... How many pieces of candy would be in one box?

explanations.A: Looking at the table, we can see that after 3 hours Macy has earned $24. 24 √∑ 3 = 8 so Macy earns $8 per hour. Looking at the graph, after 1 hour we can see Teena has earned $7. Therefore, Macy earns $1 more than Teena per hour!
explanations.B: You have correctly worked out the difference in earnings of Macy and Teena but have accidentally mixed them up!
explanations.C: I think you have accidentally compared the earnings of Macy after 1.5 hours and Teena after 1 hour. Make sure you are comparing earnings after the same amount of time worked!
explanations.D: I think you have accidentally compared the earnings of Macy after 3 hours and Teena after 1 hour. Make sure you are comparing earnings after the same amount of time worked!

explanations.A: I think you have accidentally compared the earnings of Liam after 1.5 hours and Bryan after 1 hour. Make sure you are comparing earnings after the same amount of time worked!
explanations.B: I think you have accidentally compared the earnings of Liam after 4 hours and Bryan after 1 hour. Make sure you are comparing earnings after the same amount of time worked!
explanations.C: You have correctly worked out the difference in earnings of Liam and Bryan, but have accidentally mixed them up!
explanations.D: Looking at the table, we can see that after 4 hours Liam has earned $44. 44 √∑ 4 = 11 so Liam earns $11 per hour. Looking at the graph, after 1 hour we can see Bryan has earned $13. Therefore, Bryan earns $2 more than Liam per hour!
